awd_titl_txt: RUI: Fetal programming of early brain development and emotional regulation in infants: The role of sociocultural stressors
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate whether and to what extent prenatal exposure to sociocultural stressors influences early brain development and associated emotional regulation in infants. Impairments in emotional regulation that may be shaped by prenatal experiences are of particular concern because emotional regulation is important for cognitive ability and academic success later in life. Specifically, this project will enhance basic understanding of the role of sociocultural stressors on infant emotional regulation by studying multiple factors, including infants' emotional, physiological, and attentional states, as well as mothers' self-reports. Findings will highlight perinatal factors that affect development and will uncover potential patterns among infant measurements that may uniquely characterize early risk for poor emotional regulation. This project will extend current theories of prenatal stress and infant development and provide multiple research opportunities for students, broadening participation of diverse groups in science. Moreover, this work will integrate teaching and research, a high-impact practice shown to improve learning outcomes and increase graduation rates in students. 

The project will ascertain if attention-related brain development underlies the effects of prenatal stress exposure on emotional regulation in at-risk infants. First, to determine if such brain development is related to prenatal stress exposure, mothers will report on levels of sociocultural stress experienced during their pregnancy. At birth, electrophysiological activity in the infants' brains will be assessed to evaluate brain development and attention functioning. At 6 months of age, a social stressor will be used to determine if the relationship between prenatal stress exposure and infant emotional dysregulation is strengthened by early neurodevelopment of attention functioning. While experiencing the stressor--an interaction in which a mother looks at her infant while maintaining a nonmoving, neutral facial expression--infants' heart rate variability, cortisol responses, and negative vocalizations will be measured for subsequent analysis. By using a variety of measures, inferences can be made about the potential dyssynchrony between behavioral and physiological response systems, which may itself indicate emotional dysregulation in young children. This work will utilize a multidisciplinary, multi-method approach that integrates social, behavioral, and biological levels of analysis to understand processes related to development and learning in children.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.inst_name: California State University San Marcos Corporation
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY SAN MARCOS CORP

por.por_cntn:
This work aimed to understand the role of sociocultural stressors on programming of infant emotional regulation from multiple standpoints; behavioral (negative affect), self-report (maternal), and physiological (cortisol) as well as across attentional, social and behavioral domains.

We recruited 208 mother/child of Mexican descent into our study during pregnancy and followed the pair until the infants were 6 months old (final n=156). Mothers filled out surveys related to sociocultural stressors, including cultural orientation, acculturative and discrimination, as well as adherence to traditional Mexican cultural values, during pregnancy. We performed tests of early central nervous functioning (heart rate variability and P50 auditory sensory gating paradigm) in the early postpartum period as well as maternal report of temperament and behavioral analysis of emotional regulation and the physiological response to stress (i.e. cortisol) in a Still Face paradigm late postpartum.

In the early postpartum period, prenatal exposure to maternal sociocultural stressors was not associated with heart rate variability infants. However, fetal exposure to more acculturative stress and discrimination during pregnancy was related to a more negative temperament (less surgency). There was an interaction between heart rate variability and discrimination, but not acculturative stress, on infant temperament, such that low heart variability was associated with less surgency when the mother perceived less discrimination during pregnancy and high surgency when prenatal discrimination was high.

In the later postpartum period, maternal cultural orientation was associated with infant emotional regulation, such that infants of mothers who reported higher Anglo, but not Mexican, orientation showed less negative affect and blunted cortisol response during the Still Face procedure. In addition, fetal exposure to prenatal acculturative stress and discrimination was associated with more negative affect, but not infant cortisol.

Maternal warmth, responsiveness, and non-demandingness to infant distress during the Still Face were all negatively correlated with infant vocalizations. Although maternal sensitivity was not associated with acculturation or acculturative stress there were significant correlations between specific prenatal cultural values and maternal sensitivity domains. Mothers with higher adherence to the traditional value of familism expressed more warmth towards their infants, higher enculturation was associated with decreased demandingness towards their infants, and increased familism-referent was associated with lower maternally intrusive behavior. Furthermore, less maternally intrusive speech was associated with higher overall familism, respect, and enculturation.

Overall this work suggests that fetal exposure to maternal sociocultural stressors is associated with early markers of infant temperament and emotional regulation, both biological and behavioral. Protective maternal factors, such as adherence to traditional Mexican cultural values and warm and responsive behavioral sensitivity, may buffer some the fetal programming effects of stress on later infant emotional regulation. This work opens new directions in research related to early CNS functioning on the development of emotional regulation in infants and the role of early life exposure to various types of stressors.

This project broadened participation of under-represented groups in science and provided multiple research opportunities for 22 undergraduate bilingual Latina students. Data generated from this award was analyzed and presented in 6 oral presentations and 22 posters at 17 different regional and national conferences authored by 16 different students. Of these students, 4 are in or have been accepted to PhD programs, 1 is currently in a postbac program for MD/PhD students, 5 others are in or have completed Master’s programs and 2 are applying to graduate school currently.

 


Last Modified: 03/09/2022
Modified by: Kimberly D'anna-Hernandez
